metadata.sermon_start_end: There is nothing ordinary about the key claims of biblical faith. Indeed, there is almost nothing about biblical faith that can be understood according to our usual analytical, scientific, objective, or commonsense control of life. The Bible is, rather, organized around the explosive moments when the holiness of God [...] God has not quit, and will not, until our life is joyously reflective of God’s own life. Such is our confidence that we have through Christ toward God, utter confidence.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker’s primary requirement of focusing on ONE specific passage. It treats three distinct pericopes (Exodus, Luke, 2 Corinthians) as thematic illustrations of 'holiness.' By jumping between texts, it misses the 'specific point found nowhere else' in favor of a general biblical idea.
quotes: The readings today are about a series of three such dangerous eruptions
It is the third text that concerns us, the one that looks back to Moses and to Jesus.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select only 2 Corinthians 3 and identify what this text specifically says about the 'unveiled face' that is not present in the Exodus account.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is largely absent. There is no mention of the Greek/Hebrew nuances beyond a brief mention of 'metamorphosis,' nor is there an exploration of the specific historical tensions in Corinth or the Sinai covenant context. It remains at a narrative-descriptive level.
quotes: Paul writes to the church in Corinth. It is, we know, a troubled, struggling church
He utters this odd Greek word, metamorphosis
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Analyze the specific polemic Paul is engaged in regarding the 'ministry of death' versus the 'ministry of the Spirit' to ground the sermon in historical reality.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: While the preacher attempts to address the 'zeitgeist' (technology, achievement, self-help), the applications remain somewhat rhetorical and list-like rather than deeply concrete in the lives of the hearers.
quotes: imagining the glory is to be found in our technology, in our brightness, in our achievement
ten ways to a healthy body, six steps to good sex, and four disciplines for prosperity.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond listing cultural clichés and describe how the 'glory' specifically disrupts a concrete modern situation, such as a specific local injustice or a precise psychological state.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'lecture' structure (I, II, III, IV) which separates the biblical stories from the application. The hearer is told about the text and then told about their life, rather than being 'expounded' together with the text.
quotes: But that is not what I want to talk about. It is the third text...
Paul continues to write these Christians...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the 'metamorphosis' of the text directly into the description of the modern hearer's struggle, so the text acts upon the hearer during the reading.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories of misery (despair, self-achievement) and redemption (God’s mercy, Christ’s suffering) are present in the background. However, 'gratitude' is largely replaced by 'ministry' as a human task, which risks becoming a new law.
quotes: it is by God’s mercy that we are engaged in this ministry
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure 'ministry' is clearly framed as the 'gratitude' (the response to grace) rather than a 'large work' that defines identity.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon hints at 'being lost in time' (empty claims, phoney goals), but the 'narrow way' lacks the gravity Dekker demands. There is no real sense of the 'threat' of destruction, only a 'restlessness.'
quotes: all the empty claims where God’s holiness... does not reside
the other stories which compete with it are not your true story
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the consequence of choosing the 'dominant images of society' more sharply—describe the 'destruction' or 'loss' that follows the broad way.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, but the sermon leans heavily on Christ as an 'example' of suffering or a 'pivot' rather than the ontological Savior. The 'two natures' are implied but not substantively used to ground the grace.
quotes: Jesus becomes the pivot where holiness touches humanity
in the face and body and life and story of the one who suffers
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'glory' to Christ's divinity to show why this transformation is a work of God and not a psychological shift.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1350 words, the sermon likely lasts 13-14 minutes. This is significantly below Dekker's 20-minute minimum. The 'breadth' required for 'depth' is missing; the sermon remains at the level of a thematic meditation.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and dogmatic sections to reach at least 2000 words, allowing the text to breathe and the 'oddity' of the passage to be fully explored.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its thematic approach and insufficient length. It treats the Bible as a source of 'stories' and 'claims' rather than recreating a specific pericope into a current word. The lack of rigorous exegesis and the failure to focus on a single text prevents the 'specific truth' of the Word from emerging. It functions more as a theological speech on 'holiness' than a sermon.
strengths: Avoids moralism by emphasizing that transformation 'comes from the Lord'
Correctly identifies the 'zeitgeist' of self-help and achievement as a form of misery
Maintains a sober, non-romantic view of God's holiness as 'dangerous'
weaknesses: Insufficient duration (approx. 14 minutes) prevents necessary depth
Thematic 'keyword' preaching (holiness) instead of pericope-based preaching
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker’s definition, this is not yet a sermon. It is a thematic address. It lacks the formal requirement of being an 'exposition of a specific Bible passage' and fails the 20-minute depth requirement. It is a 'bicycle mechanic' who has described the wheel but not yet mounted it.
